sn35.127:1.1: Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer declares enlightenment at SN 48.49, resulting in him being praised as the foremost in roaring a lion’s roar (AN 1.195). He was noted for his austere lifestyle (Ud 4.6), which he explained in his verses at Thag 2.2.
sn35.127:1.2: Udena of Kosambī features in Ud 7.1, a key event in the so-called “Kosambī cycle”.
sn35.127:1.5: Despite the claim here, this saying is not spoken by the Buddha in the Pali. Perhaps the original discourse was lost.
sn35.127:1.6: A healthy monastic life cannot be lived in fear and loathing of the opposite sex. A positive emotional connection is grounded in mettā, derived ultimately from the experience of familial love, just as a mother’s cherishing of her child is the basis for universal love (Snp 1.8:7.1).
sn35.127:3.2: The perception of kindness, cherishing, and love is established regarding the opposite sex, while detachment is cultivated for one’s own body.
sn35.127:5.3: With esova (“this is the real”), the king shows that he was unpersuaded by the other practices, but is convinced by this one, which agrees with his experience.
sn35.127:5.4: The antepura is the “inner sanctum”, sometimes the enclosed area of the “royal compound” (DN 14:2.2.10), but here the women’s apartments or “harem”.
